column1: Launceston ( (listen)) is a city in the north of Tasmania
column2: Australia
column3: at the junction of the North Esk and South Esk rivers where they become the Tamar River (kanamaluka). With a population of 87
column5: Launceston is the second most populous city in Tasmania after the state capital
column6: Hobart
column7: and the fifth-largest inland city in Australia.

column2: Launceston is one of Australia's oldest cities and it has many historic buildings. Like many places in Australia
column3: it was named after a town in the United Kingdom – in this case
column4: Launceston
column5: Cornwall. Launceston also had the first use of anaesthetic in the Southern Hemisphere
column6: it was the first Australian city to have underground sewers
column7: and it was the first Australian city to be lit by hydroelectricity. The city has a temperate climate with four distinct seasons. Local government is split between the City of Launceston and the Meander Valley and West Tamar Councils.

column1: The first inhabitants of the area of Launceston were largely nomadic Aboriginal Tasmanians believed to have been part of the North Midlands Tribe.
The first white visitors did not arrive until 1798
column2: when George Bass and Matthew Flinders were sent to explore the possibility that there was a strait between Australia and Van Diemen's Land (now Tasmania). They originally landed in Port Dalrymple (the mouth of the Tamar River)
column3: 40 kilometres (25 mi) to the north-west of Launceston.The first significant colonial settlement in the region dates from 1804
column4: when the commandant of the British garrison Lt. Col. William Paterson
column5: and his men set up a camp on the current site of George Town. A few weeks later
column6: the settlement was moved across the river to York Town
column7: and a year later was moved to its definitive position where Launceston stands.Initially
column8: the settlement was called Patersonia; however
column9: Paterson later changed the name to Launceston in honour of the New South Wales Governor Captain Philip Gidley King
column11: Cornwall. The name still survives in the tiny hamlet of Patersonia 18 kilometres (11 mi) north-west of Launceston. Paterson himself also served as Lieutenant-Governor of northern Van Diemen's Land from 1804 to 1808.The geographical area in which Launceston is now located was previously occupied by the Letteremairrener people. The Letteremairrener country encompasses most of the Tamar Valley region. In 1804
column12: reports from Early European voyagers describe a number of Letteremairrener camps
column13: consisting of up to ten bark huts located on either side of the Tamar River. Extensive archeological evidence suggests that occupation and usage of the Tamar basin can be dated from at least 7
column15: although it was likely used as long as 35
column18: spent the winter months near George Town and the summer months residing on Ben Lomond
column19: before returning to the banks of the Tamar River for the mutton-bird season. Campbell Macknight characterizes early British contact with the Letteremairrener people as a mixture of fear
column20: curiosity and aggression. After several aggressive encounters prompted by bands of Letteremairrener in 1806
column21: most likely as pay-back for British colonists hunting on the country without permission and for trespassing
column23: in charge of the new settlement in Launceston
column24: lead a series of putative skirmishes that were ostensibly continued by colonists until 1831. These conflicts intensified from 1827 until 1831 during the period of the Black War
column25: with genocidal expeditions occurring within the Letteremairrener country and neighbouring areas.By 1827
column27: 000 and the town had become an export centre
column28: mainly for the colony's northern pastoral industry. Small hotels and breweries began to emerge in the 1820s before larger
column29: more "substantial" hotels were built in the 1830s. Sporting groups
column31: churches and schools were often established in these hotels; however

column1: Ships from Launceston carried parties of sealers to the islands of Bass Strait early in the 19th century. They also took whalers to the coast of Victoria in the 1820s and 1830s where they established temporary bay whaling stations. Some of these temporary communities
column2: such as the ones at Portland Bay and Port Fairy
column3: were the forerunner of permanent settlement of those places.

column2: who petitioned Queen Victoria in 1847 while interned with other Aboriginal Tasmanians on Flinders Island
column3: lived for several years in Launceston as one of numerous homeless children
column4: before being taken into custody by George Augustus Robinson who sent him to the Boy's Orphan School in Hobart in 1832.Newer popular team sports such as cricket and football failed to be sustained in Launceston before the population grew substantially. The sports were initially middle class recreations
column5: as the working class found it difficult to participate after a six-day working week. Nevertheless
column6: a "demand for facilities" led to the upgrade of the Northern Tasmanian Cricket Association Ground (NTCA Ground) among other sporting facilities in the 1860s. Not long beforehand
column7: Tasmania played Victoria in Australia's first first-class cricket match at the NTCA Ground in 1851.Tin was discovered at Mount Bischoff in 1871 in north-western Tasmania
column8: starting a minerals boom. Gold mining commenced about 50 kilometres (31 mi) away in Beaconsfield in 1877. During the following two decades Launceston grew from a small town into an urban centre. In 1889
column9: Launceston was the second town in Tasmania to be declared a city
column10: after state capital Hobart. During the late 1880s a small periodical called Launceston Literary contained stories as well as memoirs of the pioneering days of the region. The publication was distributed from a store in the northern end of the town
column12: was at the time considered relatively popular

column1: According to the 2016 census of Population
column2: there were  84
column3: 153 people in Launceston.

column1: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 3.2% of the population.
80.5% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were England 3.0%
column2: New Zealand 0.8%
column3: Malaysia 0.5%
column4: Bhutan 0.5% and China 0.5%.

column1: 87.0% of people spoke only English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Nepali 0.9%
column2: Mandarin 0.9%
column3: Persian 0.3%
column4: Italian 0.2% and German 0.2%.

column1: The most common responses for religion were No Religion 36.0%
column2: Anglican 19.7% and Catholic 14.6%.

column1: Launceston is at 41°26′31″S 147°8′42″E in the Tamar Valley
column2: Northern Tasmania. The valley was formed by volcanic and glacial forces over 10 million years ago.

column1: The city is about 45 kilometres (28 mi) south of the Bass Strait
column2: with its closest neighbour-city being Devonport
column3: about 99 kilometres (62 mi) to the north west.

column1: Launceston combines steep (originally heavily wooded) ridges and low-lying areas (originally wetlands – with parts of the suburbs of Inveresk and Invermay below high-tide level).

column2: areas of Launceston are subject to landslip problems
column3: while others are liable to poor drainage and periodic flooding. The topography of the area is not conducive to easy dispersion of airborne pollution
column4: due to the phenomenon of thermal inversion.During recent years the city's air quality has improved. Studies indicate that 73% percent of air pollution in Launceston and surrounding areas during the winter period is caused by wood smoke
column5: while about 8% is from motor vehicle pollution. During the early 1990s about 60% of households used wood heaters
column6: but since the mid 2000s only 25–30% of households use wood heating. According to the 2011 Tasmanian Air Monitoring report
column7: particulate matter met the Air NEPM goals starting in 2006
column8: and did not exceed the PM10 standard in the years 2009–2011.Launceston is situated at the confluence of the South Esk River and the North Esk River
column9: forming the Tamar River estuary. It is used for commercial and recreational shipping and boating. In earlier years
column10: oceangoing shipping used the river to obtain access to the Port of Launceston wharves located in the city centre and Invermay.

column1: The Port for Launceston is now located at the George Town suburb of Bell Bay
column2: some 40 kilometres (25 mi) downstream on the east bank of the Tamar estuary
column3: close to the river mouth. The South Esk River is the longest river in Tasmania. It starts in the North East Mountains near Roses Tier and flows through the Fingal Valley where it passes through the towns of Fingal and Avoca before flowing into the Northern Midlands where it flows through the towns of Evandale
column4: Perth
column5: Longford and Hadspen before finally reaching Launceston via the Cataract Gorge. The river is dammed at Lake Trevallyn on the upper reaches of the Cataract Gorge
column6: with water being diverted into the Trevallyn Power Station with runoff flowing into the remainder of the Cataract Gorge and eventually merging with the Tamar River. The North Esk River starts in the Northallerton Valley in Tasmania's north-east mountains and winds its way to Launceston via the Corra Linn Gorge at White Hills. The St Patrick's River
column7: the largest tributary of the North Esk
column8: is dammed at Nunamara to provide the majority of Launceston's town water since the mid-1800s.

column2: parts of Launceston have been protected by a series of flood levees that reach up to 4 metres (13 ft) in height as large portions of the suburbs Invermay and Newstead sit within a flood plain. The last major flood occurred in 1929 when Invermay was completely devastated. More than 4
column3: 000 people were left homeless after just one night of flooding. Since then
column4: there have only been minor floods. Work is under way on a $59 million flood levee upgrade that should protect the city from 1-in-200-year events
column5: that is expected to take five to six years to construct. The council has acquired land used by eighteen businesses on the south side of Lindsay Street in Invermay
column6: with businesses having until July 2009 to leave. In 2016 the Tamar River flooded resulting in the widespread flooding of low lying suburbs. The St Leonards and West Tamar Highways were temporarily closed as water levels rose
column7: causing significant disruption to the city and loss of livestock.

column2: temperate climate

column1: with four distinct seasons. The city is located in the Tamar Valley and is surrounded by many large hills and mountains. With this type of topography
column2: Launceston's weather patterns can change considerably in a short period.

column1: The warmest months are in January and February with an average air temperature range of 12.2 to 24.4 °C (54 to 76 °F). Throughout the year there is an average of 4.3 days a year over 30 °C (86 °F). The maximum recorded temperature was 39 °C (102 °F) on 30 January 2009
column2: with Launceston Airport reaching 40.4 °C (105 °F) on that same day
column3: during the 2009 Southeastern Australia heat wave.

column1: Winters are cool with minimum temperatures dropping below 2 °C (36 °F) an average of 61 days a year. The coldest month is July
column2: with an average temperature range of 2.2 to 12.5 °C (36 to 55 °F).

column1: The lowest recorded minimum at Launceston's current weather station
column2: Ti Tree Bend was −5.2 °C (22.6 °F) on 21 July 1991. Launceston very rarely receives snowfall
column3: with snow falling in 1951 and 1986
column4: and again on 3 August 2015
column5: when most of the state received snowfall due to a cold front moving up from Antarctica.  On the night of 4th August 2020
column6: Launceston received an inch of snow on the ground
column7: with varying levels around the state.Winter
column9: is also the season with the least amount of wind. Because of this and the topographical effect of the Tamar Valley
column10: Launceston winters are renowned for foggy mornings
column11: with Launceston Airport the most fog-bound commercial airport in Australia. The average annual rainfall
column14: falling on an average of 88.4 days a year. The most rain Ti Tree Bend has received in a year was 829.6 millimetres (32.66 in) in 1992
column15: though Launceston Airport received 953.1 millimetres (37.52 in) in 1956. As in most of Tasmania 2006 was the driest year when just 394.8 millimetres (15.54 in) fell.The Bureau of Meteorology reported that 2007 was the warmest year ever recorded in Launceston since temperatures were first recorded in 1884. Temperatures ranged from a minimum of 8.1 °C (46.6 °F) to a maximum of 19.2 °C (66.6 °F).

column2: Launceston had the hottest maximums throughout the state. In 2008
column3: Launceston had the highest average maximum temperature out of all Tasmanian cities with 18.6 °C (65.5 °F).

column1: Many of the buildings in the City's central business district (CBD) were constructed in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries
column2: and Launceston is a major location of Federation style housing. Launceston's many well preserved Victorian and Georgian buildings (including the Launceston synagogue
column3: a rare example of architecture in Egyptian Revival style) together with its diverse collection of art-deco architecture (such as Holyman House and Lucks Corner in the CBD
column4: the former Star Theatre in Invermay and the former Launceston General Hospital) give the city an unusual period ambience. 20th Century examples of architecture that are part of the city include the Government offices of Henty House in Charles Street
column5: the Police Station Building and the ANZ Building on the corner of Brisbane & George Street.

column1: This is at least in part a matter of deliberate policy – concerns that high rise development might compromise the essential character of the city centre have led to strictly enforced building regulations that restrict the height of new structures in the city
column2: so that most buildings in the CBD have fewer than five storeys.

column1: Much of Launceston is contained within the City of Launceston local government area
column2: although some outer suburbs are part of adjacent council districts: for instance Riverside and Legana are part of the West Tamar Council; Prospect Vale and Blackstone Heights are included in the Meander Valley Council.

column1: Launceston City Council meetings are held in the Launceston Town Hall. The Mayor of the City of Launceston uses the honorific the Right Worshipful. In 2002
column2: Janie Dickenson became the youngest female elected mayor in Australia. The current mayor
column3: Albert Van Zetten
column4: who was initially elected in 2007
column5: before being re-elected in 2009

column1: State Upper House seats that incorporate parts of Launceston are the Electoral Divisions of Paterson
column2: Windermere and Rosevears. For federal elections
column3: Launceston falls within the Division of Bass
column4: with the sitting member being Bridget Archer for the Liberal Party of Australia
column5: who won the seat in the 2019 election. The state Lower House seat is also called the Division of Bass
column6: and is one of the five electorates in the Tasmanian House of Assembly. Both federal and state seats share common boundaries.

column1: The Launceston flag design is based on the city's Coat of Arms granted by the College of Arms
column2: London on 11 June 1957. The Brisbane Street Mall
column3: the War memorial at Royal Park
column4: atop the Council Chambers and on top of the Albert Hall are places in the city where the flag is regularly flown. Flying the flag is restricted to Council Property. The three intersecting lines in the flag represent the city's three rivers (North Esk
column5: South Esk and Tamar) and the two rectangles in the lines represent tin ingots. The strip across the top with the jagged edge is green to represent the city's parks
column6: gardens and surrounding countryside. Waratah flowers at the top symbolise all flowers and similar beauties of nature. The ingots are included because Launceston used to be a large tin-smelting centre. The little circle at the river junction is Launceston.

column1: Along with being a major retail centre with an average of 75% of market share in surrounding local councils
column2: Launceston is a major service centre for the north of Tasmania. The city is home to a campus of the University of Tasmania including the Australian Maritime College; and has a minor minerals and manufacturing base.

column1: Launceston is a major hub for the regional agricultural and pastoral activities. Historically
column2: this has been connected with the growing of apples – in recent years the stress has moved to viticulture. Superfine wool remains an important part of the rural economy of north-east Tasmania and wool sales in Launceston attract many international buyers. The various agricultural industries in the district are supported by the Tasmanian Institute of Agricultural Research which operates the Mount Pleasant Research Laboratories in the Launceston suburb of Prospect.

column1: Launceston serves as the commercial hub for the north of Tasmania
column2: and like many parts of the state
column3: is becoming a major tourist centre. Visitors to the city have grown over the past few years: during 2004 Launceston attracted 412
column4: 800 visitors
column5: up 51% from 2001. The United Kingdom is the origin of 25% of all international visitors to the city and 17% originate from the United States. The Cataract Gorge is Launceston's largest tourist attraction and is in close proximity to the city centre. It is home to the longest single span chairlift in the world

column1: Launceston has many parks throughout the city including City Park
column2: located next to the city centre. City Park is home to Albert Hall. The park also has a large enclosure for Japanese macaque monkeys
column3: a gift from sister city Ikeda
column4: Japan. The Launceston General Post Office dates back to the 1880s
column5: with a clock tower added in the early twentieth century. The GPO clock chime chimes every quarter-hour. Tasmania Zoo
column6: which is known for its wildlife conservation work
column7: including a breeding program for Tasmanian devils

column1: Launceston's Queen Victoria Museum and Art Gallery was established in 1891.
Now the largest museum located outside a capital city in Australia
column2: the Queen Victoria Museum and Art Gallery is located at two sites across the city: the original purpose built building at Royal Park and another at the Inveresk Cultural Precinct
column3: on the grounds of the former railway station and rail yards in buildings largely converted from the former Railway Workshops. The precinct also includes the Launceston Tramway Museum
column4: which houses the No. 29 tram
column5: the 'Mary St' shelter shed and a host of other memorabilia. The state's largest preservation railway
column6: the Don River Railway
column7: also has a carriage rebuilding workshop on the site. Australia's oldest bookshop
column8: A.W. Birchall & Sons (Birchalls) dating from November 1844
column9: is still located at its original site in Brisbane Street (now the Brisbane Street Mall).Located in the Southern Launceston suburb of Prospect
column10: the Country Club Casino is a hotel
column11: casino and golf course complex. It was the second casino to be built in Tasmania and one of the first in Australia.

column1: Sport is a popular recreational and spectator activity in Launceston and like most of the state
column2: cricket and Australian rules football are popular sports. The city has been the birthplace of two prominent Australian cricketers; the former Australian cricket captain Ricky Ponting and the retired cricketer and Australian selector David Boon. The first first-class cricket match played in Australia was at the Northern Tasmania Cricket Association Ground between the Melbourne Cricket Club and the Launceston Cricket Club in 1851.Australian rules football is very popular in Launceston
column3: and is often played at York Park (University of Tasmania Stadium). Holding 20
column4: 000 people—more than any other stadium in Tasmania—York Park was swampland before becoming Launceston's showgrounds in 1873. Hawthorn has played between two and five AFL matches each season since 2001
column5: and the St Kilda Football Club played two games a year between 2003 and 2006. In 2007
column6: the Tasmanian Government signed a A$16.4 million
column7: five-year sponsorship deal with the Hawthorn Football Club
column8: under which the club will play four regular season games and one National Australia Bank Cup pre-season match at the venue each year. Throughout its history
column9: York Park has hosted major pop concerts and other entertainments. Since 2001 it has been a venue for international sports events
column10: and in 2005 was redeveloped at a cost of $23.6 million. Association football (commonly known in Launceston as "soccer") is also played and watched in Launceston [York Park]—the only place in Tasmania to have hosted national league soccer matches. A National Soccer League game was held at Aurora Stadium in 2002 between Perth Glory and Melbourne Knights. A-League's Melbourne Victory have held a pre-season cup game at the venue each year since 2006. The record crowd is 8
column11: 061.Launceston is not represented by an NRL Football Club or an AFL Football Club
column12: though both sports have clubs playing at a local level.

column1: Rugby league football is played in the region at junior level and senior level
column2: the Launceston Warriors play in the Tasmanian Rugby League and were minor premiers in the 2012–2013 season.
the V8 Supercars (Tasmanian Challenge) has been annually held at the recently re-developed Symmons Plains Raceway
column3: which is around 30 km south of Launceston.

column2: driver of the number 9 Richard Petty Motorsports car is most likely America's most notable Launceston native. A number of other sports have notable presence in Launceston
column3: including basketball (men's
column4: women's and indoor) and hockey. In 2009 Launceston redeveloped the city's swimming facilities which now include a modern indoor multimillion-dollar swimming centre at windmill hill
column5: now named Launceston Aquatic.

column1: The city co-hosted the basketball FIBA Oceania Championship 1975

column2: and has been continually published ever since. The newspaper is currently owned by Nine Entertainment Co (Nine having merged with Fairfax Media in 2018). Another local media site is Tasmanian Times.

column1: Launceston General Hospital is Launceston's 300-bed public hospital
column2: located just south of the city centre. Every year
column3: LGH treats over 24
column4: 000 inpatients and over 225
column5: 000 outpatients. St Lukes Private Hospital and St Vincent's Hospital are the major private facilities. Launceston was also the location of the first use of anaesthesia in the Southern Hemisphere.

column1: Launceston is also the hub for the state's medical retrieval service. The Royal Flying Doctor Service supplies an aircraft and pilots under contract to the state's ambulance service and the aircraft (a Beechcraft Super King Air) is staffed by Ambulance Tasmania's Intensive Care Paramedics and doctors from the Launceston General Hospital.
University of Tasmania has its second largest campus in Launceston
column2: based in Newnham. It is currently relocating a significant portion of its campus to Inveresk.

column1: TasTAFE has two major operations in Launceston based at Alanvale and the Central Business District.
The car is by far the most dominant form of transport in Launceston
column2: with the city having 721 km of urban and rural roads
column3: even though much of the CBD has narrow one-way streets.

column2: Launceston has been serviced by the Tasmanian government-owned and operated public bus service Metro Tasmania. In addition
column3: Redline offers school services and travels to many destinations across Tasmania.

column2: Launceston is the hub of five of the state's major highways. The Midland Highway is the primary route to Hobart. The Bass Highway is the primary route to Devonport and Burnie. The Tasman Highway is an alternate scenic route to Hobart via Scottsdale
column3: the East Coast
column4: the West Tamar Highway and East Tamar Highway.

column1: The city is served by the small curfew-free Launceston Airport
column2: 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) south-east of the city. The airport serves over one million passengers annually. Jetstar Airways
column3: Virgin Australia
column4: Sharp Airlines
column5: Australian air Express and QantasLink all operate scheduled services at the airport. There are currently direct flights to and from Melbourne
column6: Sydney and Brisbane.There is a freight rail system in operation which links Launceston to Burnie

column1: The port is located on the Tamar river.
Launceston operated a suburban tramway system between 1911 and 1952
column2: which consisted of 29 trams. It was first conceived in 1909
column3: after observations of efficiently working systems in Melbourne and Adelaide. A decade before the tram system was abandoned
column4: Launceston had begun converting to trolleybuses
column5: especially for the hilly routes. The Launceston trolleybus system was one of the most extensive of the various trolleybus systems in Australia. The tramway network was finally removed in 1952 to make way for cars and buses. A tramway museum in Inveresk is all that remains of Launceston's trams. Launceston's streets
column6: most of which were planned in the early nineteenth century
column7: were probably always too narrow for trams to be fully successful: in many cases little of the roadway remained for other forms of transport. The track gauge was 1067mm (3 ft 6in).A regional passenger rail system operated in Tasmania
column8: of which Launceston was a major hub; however
column9: after many years of gradual retrenchment it was closed in July 1978.

Launceston's electricity is primarily generated by renewable hydro electric power plants including the Trevallyn Power Station which is supplied with water from Trevallyn Dam. The major retailer is Aurora Energy.

column2: Launceston was powered by gas from the Launceston Gas Company
column3: (later Gas Corporation of Tasmania). In 1988 it was sold to Boral. The first gas plant was built in 1860 as a horizontal retort Gas Works house made from brick and sandstone on the site's SW corner. This was followed by keepers cottages
column4: labs
column5: the Headquarters Building and the iconic 1930s vertical retort recognised by the wording "COOK WITH GAS" written in its brickwork. The Duck Reach Power Station replaced gas for street lighting when it was completed in 1895 (the first municipally owned power station in the Southern Hemisphere). Until the 1950s when Trevallyn Power Station was built
column6: Duck Reach supplied Launceston with most of its power needs – it is now an interpretive historic site. The former Gas Works houses a Cafe.

column1: Launceston's water comes from the Launceston Water Catchment. The majority is sourced from St Patricks River
column2: a tributary of the North Esk River which flows through Launceston. The main retailer is Ben Lomond Water. The first reticulated water supply constructed in 1857 still serves the CBD. There were fears that the Tamar Valley Pulp Mill might adversely affect Launceston's water supply.Like many Australian cities
column3: several major companies provide mobile telecommunications services and wireless internet services to Launceston. Launceston's communication infrastructure was upgraded in 1997 through the federal "Networking the Nation" program. There are plans to upgrade further to a fibre optic network.
